Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Reconstruction of the eastern Bering ice-ocean system by variational assimilation of the BEST-BSIERP data
Award.AbstractNarration:
Funds are provided to achieve three major goals.
1. To synthesize data from the BEST-BSIERP coordinated programs in the Bering Sea and data from other sources, collected during the same time period (2007-2010), via modeling and data assimilation. Two joint data assimilation systems will be applied to reconstruct the physical oceanographic fields of the eastern Bering ice-ocean system. The first system will be configured to reconstruct the large-scale circulation in the eastern Bering Sea and to accurately describe the large-scale processes in the South Eastern Bering Sea Shelf. The second will be configured for the eastern Bering Sea Shelf and will explicitly resolve eddy and tidal dynamics, thus leading to a better understanding of the nonlinear interaction processes between the deep basin and the shelf region of the eastern Bering Sea.
2. To analyze the reconstructed fields and identify processes important for causing observed variability.
3. To determine the impact of assimilating data with different origins on the estimation of near-surface transports of volume, momentum, heat, and material. This will be accomplished through adjoint sensitivity analysis. Results will help optimize Bering Sea mooring observations in future studies.

The Bering Sea is the largest commercial and subsistence fishery of the United States. Management of this fishery in the face of ongoing climate variability requires an understanding of all the processes impacting the fishery. Amongst these are the changing water temperature, which influences the growth rate of fish, and the current field, which carries fish eggs and larvae from their spawning regions to their nursery grounds. This project will contribute to an understanding of how these fields change in response to other external forcing.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The eastern Bering Sea (EBS) supports the United States' most valuable fisheries, immense populations of marine birds and mammals, and subsistence activities of Native communities. This extraordinarily productive ecosystem is vulnerable to the significant climate variability that has occurred over recent decades. To assess the vulnerability of this ecosystem, it is essential to understand how the eastern Bering Sea physical and ecological dynamics responds to climate change. Since 2007, two major research programs have been launched: the Bering Sea Ecosystem STudy (BEST), supported by the NSF, and the Bering Sea Integrated Ecosystem Research Program (BSIERP), supported by the NPRB. The BEST-BSIERP research has yielded an unprecedented number of observations of sea ice, the ocean, and the ecosystem in the EBS.

Intellectual Merit: The rich collection of BEST-BSIERP observations and other sources of data provide an excellent opportunity for synthesis through modeling and Data Assimilation (DA) to improve our understanding of changes in the physical forcings of the Bering ecosystem in response to climate change. As part of the NSF BEST program, this collaborative research project was aimed to develop two joint DA systems for the EBS.  These two joint DA systems consist of the Bering Ecosystem STudy ice-ocean Modeling and Assimilation System (BESTMAS) linked to the Semi-Implicit Ocean Model (SIOM) four-dimensional variational (4DVar) DA system and to the Regional Ocean Modeling System’s (ROMS) DA system. They were used as a tool to maximize the impact of BEST-BSIERP research by synthesizing the BEST-BSIERP data and data from other sources via modeling and DA, and therefore to enhance our understanding of climate variability and change in the EBS sea ice–ocean system.

Broader Impacts: Three collaborating teams were involved in this project: lead PI Dr. Gleb Panteleev at the University of Alaska Fairbanks (SIOM), PI Dr. Alexandr Kurapov at Oregon State University (ROMS), and PI Dr. Jinlun Zhang at the University of Washington (BESTMAS). This collaborative project supported 2 postdoctoral researchers and 2 PhD graduate students. Four project webpages were created and maintained to promote BEST research and education and to store sea ice and ocean results for public access: http://people.iarc.uaf.edu/~gleb/best_reanalysis/best_reanalysis.html, http://psc.apl.washington.edu/BEST, http://ingria.coas.oregonstate.edu/news/Bering.html, and http://ingria.coas.oregonstate.edu/news/Amukta_pass.html. In particular, the nested SIOM 4DVar DA system is able to provide gridded data sets that are physically consistent and constrained to the observations of sea ice and ocean parameters.
